body: Same problem here. I tried to work around the problem by doing a resize in my application to see if that would trigger the drawing, but it seems that only a manual resize or move of the window will trigger the drawing.
glfw just needs to call update() on the NSGLContext a couple of times before swapping the buffers. https://github.com/kovidgoyal/kitty/commit/b82e74f99ae30599cd88ef6a1216625b57a0414a
you dont need to do that, just call the update method on the nsglcontext object, as I demonstrated in the commit I linked to earlier.

body: I noticed that the Gears example works fine, and stops working when removing `glfwWindowHint(GLFW_TRANSPARENT_FRAMEBUFFER, GLFW_TRUE);` from it. So I guess that making transparent buffers could also be a work-around.

Here's a workaround that worked for me:

Use `glfwWindowHint(GLFW_TRANSPARENT_FRAMEBUFFER, GLFW_TRUE);` before creating the window.

If the application results with transparency in the frame buffer and background is showing through the window, clear your frame buffer's alpha (using `glColorMask`, `glClearColor`, and `glClear`) before swapping buffers.

issue.body: Due to the depreciation of OpenGL on macOS, a window created by glfw isn't drawn to until NSOpenGLContext is updated, seen [here](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/issues/1334#issuecomment-425298183). I have a workaround that calls the update [here](https://github.com/Noofbiz/glfwMojaveFix) that fixes the issue if it's called just before window.SwapBuffer(). I'm wondering if you want this integrated into this repo somewhere, and if so how would you like me to go about doing so? Thanks!
